Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Kinetics of Phosphorus-Containing Compounds Used as Fire Suppressants and Chemical Agent Surrogates

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Compounds containing phosphorus have modern, global ramifications because of their use as promising fire suppressants. The alternate usage of these phosphorous compounds as promising replacements for halon-based fire suppressants provides additional, far-reaching impact and a strong need for sufficient understanding of their chemical behavior. These compounds can also be used as chemical agent simulants to understand more about their behavior in flames. In this research project, the chemistry of phosphorus-based molecules will be studied experimentally. The primary result will be an accurate representation of the important chemical reactions that occur in flames containing these phosphorous compounds. Improved models can then be employed by engineers and scientists. This multidisciplinary project will allow opportunities for the graduate students, postdoctoral researcher, and undergraduate students working on the project to publish and attend conferences in fields in which they might not normally participate.

The compounds of interest to this project are phosphorus-based. A major aspect of accurately predicting their combustion behaviors lies in the accuracy of the phosphorus-oxidation kinetics sub-mechanism. Despite their current importance, there are few kinetics data at combustion conditions for these compounds, and the chemical kinetic reaction rate coefficients are not at all well known. This fundamental study will focus on making direct measurements of the reaction rate constants of key reactions in the phosphorus oxidation sub-mechanism. The fundamental chemical kinetics information produced from this work will be one-of-a-kind and will provide results that are much needed for simulating the effects of P-containing compounds in a combustion environment. By using a shock tube to produce the high-temperature conditions (1000 to 2000 K), laser absorption measurements of key intermediate species such as PO2, HOPO, H2O, and HOPO2 will be performed. New spectroscopic information thereon will be obtained, and laser absorption measurements of their concentrations will be performed for the first time in a shock tube. Such measurements will lead to determination of the reaction rates of several important reactions (up to 6) for the first time. The successful completion of this project will greatly advance the predictive capabilities for the combustion behavior of several phosphorus-containing species of practical and topical interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phosphorus-based compounds are becoming increasingly important for two seemingly unrelated combustion applications: fire suppressants and simulants for chemical weapons such as Sarin. Examples include TMP, DMMP, TEP, and DIMP, among others. In both applications, a key to accurately predicting the combustion behavior of the compounds lies in the accuracy of the phosphorus-oxidation kinetics sub-mechanism. Despite their current importance, there are few kinetics data at combustion conditions for these compounds, and the chemical kinetic reaction rate coefficients are not at all well known. This project focused on the development of a laser absorption diagnostic to measure the concentration of key species in a shock tube, with emphasis on P-containing species. By using a shock tube to produce the high-temperature conditions (1000 ? 2000 K), laser absorption measurements PH3 and other key species such as N2O, H2O, and CO were performed. The reaction rate of the phosphine (PH3) decomposition reaction was measured for the first time, where phosphine is a key phosphorus precursor material used for P-related chemical kinetics measurements.

 

A major portion of the study was the development of a laser absorption diagnostic for PO2 using a quantum cascade laser (QCL) and related optical components, acquired under the present funding, in the infrared region near 7.4 mm. Identification of the PO2 species and related spectroscopic transitions proved difficult at the high-temperature shock-tube conditions. Precursor molecules such as TEP, DMMP, phosphoric acid, and phosphine were used to produce the PO2 in mixtures with O2 highly diluted in argon. During the development of the technique and the refinement of the procedures, the same laser diagnostic and shock-tube setup but with a different QCL was used to study N2O near 4.6 mm which resulted in a direct measurement of the rate of its decomposition to N2 + O at elevated temperatures. Additional measurements in the N2O and NO2 systems were performed to further develop OH* chemiluminescence chemistry at elevated temperatures.

 

Intellectual Merit: New spectroscopic information was obtained for PO2, PH3, and N2O, and laser absorption measurements of their concentrations were performed in a shock tube. The kinetic rate coefficients of PH3 and N2O decomposition were measured, with the present study being the first to measure the rate for PH3 + M = PH2 + H + M. A new laser absorption diagnostic for N2O was developed, leading to further refinement of the rate for the important reaction N2O + M = N2 + O + M. Overall, the work performed over the duration of this project has resulted in 5 journal publications, with a sixth under preparation at the time of this reporting. 

 

Broader Impact: This multidisciplinary project allowed mechanical engineering students and a senior research associate with a physical chemistry background to interact on a daily basis; there was also the opportunity for the main doctoral graduate student to mentor REU (research experiences for undergraduates) students working on the project (within an REU site, also under NSF funding). The chemical kinetics and spectroscopic information produced under this project will help with the current and future development of chemical kinetics models for phosphorus-based compounds and for nitrogen-oxide-related chemistry at combustion temperatures. The QCL diagnostic and related equipment developed in this project will be used for many more scientific studies in the principal investigator?s laboratory over the next 10 ? 20 years.
